awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   SSDIM:   Simulated and Synthetic Data for Interdependent Communications and Energy Critical Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will develop new mathematical foundations and computer-based learning theories for generating a wide range of simulated and fully-synthetic datasets that model interdependent communications and energy infrastructures in urban settings. These enhanced datasets and associated data building tools will provide a large-scale test data related to interdependent critical infrastructures (ICIs). New simulated and synthetic data generation tools will enable increasing the resiliency and flexibility of ICIs, improving their security during extreme weather conditions and other threats. This project will involve students from diverse backgrounds in engineering, computer science and psychology, who will be trained on pertinent research approaches related to the challenges of simulated and synthetic data modeling. The education plan includes a new data-centric course called Methods for Creating Simulated and Synthetic Data, as well as a large-scale involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in big data and smart community research. Broad dissemination is ensured by enabling an open-access repository of datasets created from the results of the funded research, as well as any program codes or related tools used to generate and analyze such data. The open-access testbed is capable of supporting both the research needs of the host institution as well as the requirement of non-proprietary multi-domain open datasets by other users.

This project will develop a scientific basis for the generation of simulated and synthetic data on ICIs, such as communication and energy. The objective is to develop models that can accurately reconstruct, simulate, and evaluate a robust theoretical framework of ICI function by leveraging available real-world datasets. This research will lead to several innovations: 1) An advanced Transfer Learning technique that generates simulated data on ICIs using available real-world information, leading to improved characterization of how interdependencies can form or disappear over time; 2) a Hierarchical Bayesian method-based technique for the creation of synthetic data that enables ICIs to optimally manage their shared resources in response to failures from day-to-day operations, natural disasters, or malicious attacks; 3) a Long-/Short-term Memory-based deep learning method for predicting simulated data on human-in-the-loop cognitive modeling of human behavior and the effects of their decision-making in response to unexpected incidents and events involving urban ICIs; and 4) a quality-feedback loop verification and data management approach to fine-tune the simulated and synthetic data by comparing it against available real-world data over a realistic network with a large-scale simulator that integrates ICIs over an urban setting.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
During the period of this award, FIU, and Rutgers University have developed techniques for the synthesis of data of the interdependent critical infrastructures (ICI). The need for synthetic data rises as the problems inherent in actual data present themselves in the forms of privacy and data sharing concerns and restrictions, in balancing datasets for supervised machine learning, and in simulations of events in ICIs. Developing a model for the synthesis of smart grid data was accomplished through this award. The synthesized data is highly alike the data observed in the field, based on analysis of the data. The synthesized data itself is independent of identifying values that are in the field data and thus the concerns with data confidentiality are addressed, which can help future research of the smart grid through increased access to data.

A long-short-term-memory memory model and a separate mixture density network model were designed for the generation of synthetic data. The challenge was in capturing the tendencies and events in the underlying field data without leaking identifying characteristics of the underlying data as that would breach the privacy objective of data synthesis. The mixture density network (MDN) model was found as the ideal generator due to the nature of its design as a mathematical tool. The model itself is initiated by a time-dependent neural network, the output layer is a mixture of normal distributions that model the probability of a value within different ranges. This type of model by design imparts an amount of noise in the data that passes through it. After the model is fit to the field data, only an initial sequence of data is fed to the model and recursive generation of data begins.

In this project, the optimal model based on analysis of synthesized data was shown to be the MDN. The data was analyzed through lag plots, error metrics, and frequency of events in the data. The MDN was able to capture the frequency of events in a more precise manner than the long-short-term-memory memory model. The MDN synthetic data generator also produced data with lower error and data which more closely aligned with the patterns observed in the lag plot when compared to the lag plots of field data. Specifically, two overlapping boxes and a diagonal line were observed in the lag plots, the diagonal indicating autocorrelation of the data.

To effectively model the interdependencies between critical infrastructures and increase the understanding of how communities respond to and are impacted by the ICI, data from energy consumption, human behavioral impacts, and communication networks are required. Consumer load patterns are synthesized and the quality of the synthetic data makes it representative of field data and viable for simulations or other studies of the consumer load on the grid. Additionally, the MDN generator model can be applied to a plethora of other data sources from the field of power electronics sensors and communication networks.

Furthermore, synthetic data was utilized in the study of cyberattacks in the smart grid. A falsified data attack on a photovoltaic (PV) power plant was studied as a signal detection problem. Such a false data attack would interfere with distributed energy controls possibly leading to hardware damage at the feeder level. A signal from the production meter is processed along with a ground truth irradiance signal. A multilayer perceptron outperformed a support vector classifier in the detection of the falsified data, in the supervised learning problem. Surveying vulnerabilities of the smart grid to various forms of active and passive cyberattacks has identified dangers to the confidentiality integrity and availability of the smart grid's systems. New integrations of intelligent electronic devices have resulted in a larger number of attack sites; with additional potential for malicious disruptive actions such as replay, masquerade, fake data, and denial of service assaults. Customer and employee protection strategies for mitigation techniques are identified in the research.

The research resulted in improved and newly developed courses by presenting new content, concepts, thoughts, and case studies. The research fostered strong collaboration and communication between the PI and research faculty at Rutgers University, encouraging them to pursue new research projects and collaborate in new ways.

The investigation and generation of realistic synthetic data of the ICI have been furthered in this research, extending knowledge of the process of data synthesis, the management of data, and the significance of data in the power grid concerning cyber-vulnerabilities.

These efforts have resulted in several papers in prestigious journals and conferences, as well as a large volume of new information brought to the literature in the fields of synthetic data, data management, and security.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Arif Sarwat
